plugins.name: Design to System
plugins.description:
Design to System is a Figma plugin that helps you convert your existing designs into a structured design system ‚Äî effortlessly.

With just a few clicks, you can extract styles from your design, register them as local styles, and reapply them consistently across your file.


Key Features

  1. üîç Analyze Selection : Extracts all design style properties (colors, text styles, shadows) from the selected layers. Color values are automatically categorized into background, text, and stroke styles for easier organization.
  2. üìå Register Styles : Registers the extracted styles into your Figma local styles panel. This enables consistent reuse and supports design system creation.
  3. üéØ Apply Styles : Applies the registered local styles back to the selected design elements ‚Äî ensuring consistency and systemization.
plugins.tagline: Turn your designs into a reusable system ‚Äì automatically.

plugins.name: JSON Frame Mapper
plugins.description:
# JSON Frame Mapper: Figma Plugin


## Main use case


You have a number of items with data in a collection as a single source of truth.


You also have a Figma design which you would like to use as a template.


You would like to create as many items as you have in your collection, with the data from each item using your Figma design as a template.


Wouldn't it be useful to map the data to the template, press a button and - BAM! - loads of content based on the template with the data from your collection?


I think so.


---


This plugin is completely free so feel free to not buy me a [coffee](https://buymeacoffee.com/shragor)


Although... if you did, you could leave a message asking for functional upgrades which I would consider ü§î


---


## How the thing works


1. Install the plugin in Figma (you should know how to do this)

2. Pick the frame you want to use as a template

3. Alter the fieldNames you want populated with your JSON data - note, change the name of the field, not the value - by surrounding them like {{this}}

4. Open the plugin (you can do this at any time tbh)

5. Click "Load JSON File" to load your JSON file (check next section for the required format)

6. If your frame is not selected, select it by clicking its name

7. JSON Frame Mapper will attempt to map {{fieldNames}} to Fields

8. You can manually change the mapping of fieldNames to JSON fields if you want to

9. Set "Generation Settings". Frames are generated from left to right starting from the right of the template (so make sure you have room!)

10. Frame separation sets the number of pixels between generated frames

11. Max horizontal frames sets the maximum number of frames generated to the right before it moves to a new line below the first generated frames

12. The "Generate Frames" button is there but I don't remember why. Give it a shot and see if anything happens


---


## The data


Currently the **JSON Frame Mapper** accepts only a JSON in this form:


```

[

{

"name": [Item 1's name/title],

"field1": [VALUE],

"field2": [VALUE],

...

},

{

"name": [Item 2's name/title],

"field1": [VALUE],

"field2": [VALUE],

...

},

...

]

```


So, an array of objects with key/value pairs or fields of whatever you want to call them.


In my use case, the keys correspond to column headings in a spreadsheet I output to JSON. Each row beneath the column headings is a single item I want to use with the template.


---


## Other stuff


- The plugin will look for a JSON field of "name", "Name", "title" or "Title" and use it as the name for the generated frame

- On successfully loading a JSON, it will display the number of items and fields such as ```25 items with 23 fields loaded```

- It looks for {{fieldNames}} whenever a frame is selected so you can deselect or select another frame/template after the JSON is loaded

- You can't load another or different JSON once you have loaded the first one. Unfortunately, the only way you can change JSON once loaded is:

1. Closing the Plugin

2. Exiting Figma

3. Uninstalling Figma

4. Uninstalling Windows or if Mac, upgrade your Mac to the latest silicon

5. Reinstalling Windows or opening your new Mac

6. Installing Figma

7. Installing JSON Frame Mapper Plugin

8. Opening the Plugin

- Note: only steps 1 and 8 are required for most people to clear the JSON file


## Similar plugins I tried and didn't like


- JSON -> content

- Google Sheets Sync

- Google Sheets ‚Üí Figma

- Data Lab

- Google Sheets Sync

- Data Populator

- others I can't remember


## Language clarification


You *probably* don't need to read this.


*Frame* = A Figma frame, you should know what this is. It will contain your Template


*Template* = A frame where you have all the design done and text fields in place but need lots of versions of each with different text (which is in your JSON file)


*fieldNames* = The name for a field/text field etc. in your Figma Frame/Template. Some of these will contain the text you want lots of different versions of


*Item* = An individual thing in your JSON file which contains many Fields each with the data you want to map to your fieldNames and add to your Template


*Fields* = These are the names/titles/keys of the data in your JSON. Each Item will have one or more of these and each Field can be mapped to none, one or many fieldNames in the Template


*Value* = The actual value for a given Field of a given Item in your JSON. Hopefully, this will eventually appear in a Template if everything goes well


*Map* = Linking of a fieldName to a Field
plugins.tagline: Create new instances of a frame/template from JSON data

networkAccess.reasoning: This plugin allows users to load images and data from their local development servers. Users often run local servers on common ports (3000, 4000, 5000, 8000, 8080, 9000) to serve images, SVG files, and JSON data that they want to import into their Figma designs. Localhost access enables seamless integration with local development workflows and self-hosted content.

137181.release_notes:
Now accepts and imports SVGs.

If an object {{field}} (a rectangle or square, say) is mapped to a SVG, the object will be replaced by a frame containing a group of the SVG. The SVG will be exactly the same size, shape and location (in the design) as the parent {{field}}
137181.tagline: Create new instances of a frame/template from JSON data

plugins.description:
# Image Aspect Ratio & Background Blur Generator Plugin


## Overview


This Figma plugin automatically generates a new frame from selected images (or rectangles with image fills),

with a **specified aspect ratio and width, and a blurred background**.


- Useful for creating SNS thumbnails and other aspect-ratio-fixed images

- Supports batch processing of multiple images at once


---


## Main Features


- **Aspect Ratio & Width Customization**

Choose from custom ratios or presets (16:9, 4:3, 1:1, etc.). You can freely specify the width (px).


- **Background Blur Effect**

The original image is enlarged and blurred as the background, with the original image centered. Blur strength and scale are adjustable.


- **Batch Processing**

Select multiple images or rectangles with image fills and generate all at once.


- **Automatic Saving & Restoration of Settings**

Your last-used settings are saved in Figma's clientStorage and automatically restored on next launch.


- **Japanese UI**

Intuitive and easy-to-use Japanese interface.


---


## How to Use


1. **Select images or rectangles with image fills**

Multiple selection is supported.


2. **Launch the plugin**

Set the aspect ratio, width, blur strength, and scale in the UI.


3. **Click the "Create" button**

A new frame with the specified ratio, width, and blurred background will be generated to the right of the selected image(s).


4. **Notification**

Success and error messages are shown at the bottom of the UI with color distinction.


---


## Notes


- Non-image nodes are automatically skipped.

- Settings are saved per Figma file.


---


## Data Security


- This plugin does **not** send any user data, images, or personal information to external servers.

- All settings are stored locally using Figma's `clientStorage` API.

- No external API or server communication is performed.


---

plugins.name: Reverse Variable Order
plugins.description:
Easily reverse the order of your variable values with


  1. Select your collection
  2. Select the target mode or all modes
  3. Enter the path to a group of variables
  4. Reverse


Tip

  1. Keep your variable window open to see the changes.
  2. Use the Refresh button to pull in changes to the variables made when the plugin window is open. (see below for copy & paste)
  3. Use clear to quickly delete the path.


Plugin Notes

  1. Variable names and paths are case sensitive.
  2. Updating variables, especially those linked to text styles may take longer to propagate.


Copy/Paste Figma Bug

If you copy/paste variables between collections, you may need to reload the tab in order for those variables to register in their new collection.

accepted.name: Murph
accepted.description: Systems Designer ‚Ä¢ Plugin Author ‚Ä¢ Rectangle Lover

plugins.tagline: Flip the order of values in your variable groups

plugins.name: SuperLayer (copy)
plugins.description:
SuperLayer (copy) lets you quickly view and copy the names of selected layers in your Figma file or FigJam board. It‚Äôs ideal for generating UI inventories, documentation, or simply organizing your layer structure. The plugin also shows each layer‚Äôs type and a thumbnail preview when available.


To use it, select one or more layers on your canvas and launch the plugin. A clean list view will appear with sorting options and checkboxes to include or exclude layers. Click the Copy button to copy all selected layer names to your clipboard, formatted line by line. The list updates automatically as you change your selection.


SuperLayer is optimized for speed and simplicity. It does not currently support exporting full metadata, nested hierarchy structures, or annotations. Thumbnails are generated when possible, but may not appear for certain FigJam elements or complex Figma nodes.
plugins.tagline: Copy Figma and FigJam layer names with ease. Sortable and perfect for docs, audits, and checklists

plugins.name: Fig-Refactor
plugins.description:
Call for Sponsorship: Support the Development


Fig-Refactor ‚Äì Replace Spacing with Figma Variables in One Click


Fig-Refactor is a Figma plugin designed to bring structure and scalability to your design files by replacing hardcoded gaps and paddings with Figma variables ‚Äî in bulk.


Fig-Refactor intelligently scans your selection or entire file, matches raw spacing values to the closest variable from your local or team library, and replaces them with a single click. It even skips values already using variables, keeping your workflow non-destructive and efficient.


‚ú® Features:

  1. üîç Smart matching ‚Äì Suggests the closest variable for each spacing value
  2. üß† Supports team libraries ‚Äì Load and use variables from shared libraries
  3. üìÅ Flexible scanning ‚Äì Target specific selections or scan the entire file
  4. üö´ Non-destructive ‚Äì Ignores values already assigned to a variable


Currently in active development, Fig-Refactor is already making design systems cleaner and easier to manage ‚Äî and with your support, it can go even further. Your sponsorship helps fund ongoing development, bug fixes, and new features like auto-thresholds, preview modes, and batch review.


üìπ DEMO

‚ù§Ô∏è Support this project


Your support helps keep this plugin alive and evolving.

Thank you for making design better for everyone!

plugins.name: TOC Please - Auto TOC Generator
plugins.description:
A plugin that helps you easily explore and manage complex Figma pages by generating a Table of Contents (TOC).


Features

1. In-plugin TOC generation

  1. Automatically collects frames with a specified prefix to generate a TOC
  2. Currently sorts frames based on their X-axis position on the Figma canvas (support for layer order coming soon)
  3. Click items to instantly navigate to the corresponding frame
  4. Supports up to 2 levels of nested items


2. Canvas TOC generation

  1. Create a TOC frame directly on the Figma canvas
  2. The TOC frame is fully customizable to suit your needs.
  3. When TOC content changes, simply select the TOC frame and click ‚ÄúUpdate‚Äù to refresh the content while preserving your custom styles.
plugins.tagline: Auto-generate a TOC from frames with a specific prefix.‚Ä®Click items to quickly navigate.

plugins.name: Round Off
plugins.description:
This plugin helps avoid the Figma export bug where any decimal values in a frame's position values are are rounded up on export, resulting in a subpixel white line on the sides of your exported PNGs.


Apply to all top-level frames or to just to frames selected and remove all decimal values from the x and y positions before export.


Never see that white line again!

plugins.name: Export to Denada
plugins.description:
Effortlessly create, customize, and refine HTML emails in seconds with Denada. Your brand. Your voice. Your rules. It's like magic.


This plugin is the easiest way to export your Figma designs into Denada.


How to Export Images to Denada:


  1. In Figma, select a layer to export, then right-click > Plugins > Export to Denada
  2. Name the image, paste in Denada API Token then Export to Denada
  3. The exported image will now appear in your Denada image collection


The image is linked.


  1. If you alter your image on Figma, just export it again and click "update available" in Denada


How to get a Denada API Token:


  1. In Denada, go to Settings (User must be a manager or higher)
  2. Click Create Token, Name Token
  3. Copy Token
plugins.tagline: Export your Figma assets to Denada's image library, in one click.

plugins.name: Figmata
plugins.description: Figmata is a tool that brings data visualization into the Figma environment, letting designers map data directly onto design elements with live, visual feedback. Unlike rigid chart tools like Excel or Illustrator, Figmata enables custom, flexible, and interactive graphics‚Äîintegrated into the design systems designers already use. It lowers the barrier to entry compared to D3 by working within Figma's component-based structure and offering code autocompletion for advanced users. Figmata supports CSV/JSON input, direct manipulation of visual properties, and saves state for iterative work. It bridges the gap between data and UI design, making data-rich interfaces more intuitive and design-friendly.
plugins.tagline: Data-driven design directly in Figma

plugins.name: Feed Names, Get Frames (16:9, 1280x720)
plugins.description:
This plugin allows to batch-create 1280*720px (16:9) frames with user-defined names.


The frames will be created in the centre of the viewport, unless something is in the way ‚Äî in this case it will place them to the bottom right of the conflicting element, and the frames created will remain selected for further batch manipulation. Frame size works well for YouTube thumbnails.


Useful for established design workflows, especially centred around YouTube design, with high volumes and short turnaround times.


Assuming that 1 manual frame creation+naming takes 5 seconds, then for 10 frames the plugin increases the efficiency by x50. And even more for a larger number of frames.

accepted.name: Alexandra (Sasha) Hunter
accepted.description: I do graphic and product design.

plugins.tagline: Paste a list of titles ‚Äî¬†get frames with those titles

plugins.name: Layout Aware Renaming
plugins.description:
Features

- Auto-Detect Grids: Automatically detects rows and columns in your selection.

- Custom Naming: Add prefixes and choose between numeric or alphabetic suffixes.

- Manual Override: Specify exact rows/columns when auto-detection fails.

- Mixed Sizes: Works with elements of different sizes in the same grid.

- Figma & FigJam: Compatible with both Figma and FigJam (limited support).

plugins.name: Maruco
plugins.description:
What is this?

Maruco is a plugin that provides rules and validation for component naming, helping you identify components that violate naming conventions and elements.


1. Selecting naming convention.

There are several conventions, let's select the best one for your project.


2. Entering naming elements.

Next, you can enter "words" that makes up the component's name.

Enter a comma between words to set multiple words.

Maruco guesses that the component's name is made up of three elements: a prefix, a middle word and a suffix.


3. Running validation.

That's all. Let's run the validation.
plugins.tagline: Effortless rule creation for component naming.

plugins.description:
Introduction

This plugin enables users to create beautiful and interactive charts directly within Figma. Whether you need a bar, line, donut, or pie chart, the plugin offers real-time updates and customizable styles for seamless data visualization.


Function Description

  1. Create different chart types: Line, Bar, Donut, and Pie charts.
  2. Customize chart styles with predefined themes or use custom colors.
  3. Easily add, edit, and remove data rows with an intuitive interface.
  4. Export generated charts directly as Figma frames for further design use.
  5. Support for multiple languages, including English, Simplified Chinese, Traditional Chinese, Hindi, Japanese, and Korean.


Usage Instructions

  1. Select the chart type you want to create.
  2. Input the required data and choose a predefined color scheme or customize it.
  3. Set the chart dimensions (width and height) as per your design needs.
  4. Click "Generate Chart" to create the chart frame in Figma.
  5. Customize the chart further by adjusting colors and data points as needed.


Notes

  1. The plugin supports dynamic data updates and real-time chart previews.
  2. Ensure that all necessary data rows are filled to avoid incomplete chart generation.
  3. You can switch between chart types to explore different data visualizations.

plugins.name: CSV to Table in Figma
plugins.description:
Transform your data into editable tables directly within Figma with the CSV to Table plugin. This plugin allows you to easily import and visualize your data in a structured format. Perfect for designers who need to incorporate data tables into their wireframes without the hassle of manual entry.


Key Features:


‚Ä¢ Easy Import: Upload CSV files to automatically generate tables.

‚Ä¢ Customizable Layouts: Define the number of rows and columns, and customize cell dimensions.

‚Ä¢ Drag and Drop: Convenient drag-and-drop functionality for file uploads.

‚Ä¢ Data Visualization: Instantly convert raw data into a clean, editable table format.

‚Ä¢ Integration: Seamlessly works within Figma to enhance your design workflow.


Say goodbye to tedious data entry and hello to efficient data visualization. Enhance your Figma projects with structured tables in just a few clicks!
plugins.tagline: Transform Data Files into Editable Tables in Figma

plugins.name: Awesome Bulk Metadata Importer

Sample CSV and JSON template

plugins.name: DeepL Translator
plugins.description:
DeepL Translator


A Figma plugin that quickly translates text within frames using the DeepL API.

The acceleration feature enables faster translations and cost savings.


Features


  1. üöÄ Fast Translation: Re-use past translation history for fast fast translation
  2. üí∞Ô∏è Cost Saving: Save API Usage by Re-use past translation history
  3. üåê Multi-language Support: Supports 29 languages
  4. üìö Glossary Support: Use DeepL glossaries for consistent translations
  5. üåç Auto Detection: Automatic source language detection
  6. üìù Non-destructive: Creates new frames for translations while preserving originals
  7. üéØ Simple Operation: Just select languages and click translate


How to Use


  1. Get a DeepL API key (see below)
  2. Select a frame containing text to translate
  3. Choose source and target languages
  4. (Optional) Select a glossary
  5. Click "Translate"
  6. Translation results appear in a new frame


Getting a DeepL API Key


1. Sign up for a DeepL account at DeepL Pro

  1. Free plan available (500,000 characters/month)
  2. Pro plan available for more usage

2. Get your API key:

  1. Log in to your DeepL account
  2. Go to "Account" ‚Üí "API keys"
  3. Copy your API key

3. Enter your API key in the plugin settings


Supported Languages


See the complete list of supported languages for details.


Major languages include:


  1. English (EN)
  2. Chinese (ZH)
  3. Korean (KO)
  4. German (DE)
  5. French (FR)
  6. Spanish (ES)
  7. Italian (IT)
  8. Dutch (NL)
  9. Japanese (JA)
  10. Portuguese (PT)
  11. Russian (RU)


And 18 more languages


Notes


  1. DeepL API key required (available with free plan)
  2. Free plan includes 500,000 characters per month
  3. Source language must be specified when using glossaries
  4. API keys are securely encrypted and stored


Support & Feedback


We welcome your feedback! Please contact to developer through:


- Contact Form for:

  1. Questions & Inquiries
  2. Feature Requests
  3. Bug Reports
  4. General Feedback


Privacy

  1. DeepL API keys are securely encrypted
  2. Translation data is processed on DeepL servers and not stored
plugins.tagline: Translate texts in Figma by DeepL
